;;; 沿着莫斯科主干道之一乘坐出租车几分钟后，我就感到焦虑。司机似乎转向了错误的方向，我们在拥挤的车流中前行。 “桥下和路堤上的速度更快，”我大胆地说。他咒骂了一声，然后点击了手机屏幕上的地图。他的导航应用程序快速连续地闪烁不同的路线，然后冻结。

;

;像这里的大多数出租车司机一样，他不是来自莫斯科，也不熟悉莫斯科的街道：他完全依赖应用程序来找到周围的路。他告诉我，现在它们每天都会结冰好几次。信号干扰对乘客来说也是一个问题：当我试图叫出租车时，应用程序会将我带到城市中的随机地点，这些地点离我站的地方很远，或者只是说，“地理位置问题，请稍后再试”;

;;当我尝试叫出租车时，应用程序只是说：“地理位置问题，请稍后再试”;

;

;急转弯穿过繁忙的车道，回到我的轨道上到达目的地后，出租车短暂经过克里姆林宫。 “他们屏蔽了;GPS;，我们受尽痛苦，”司机抱怨道。人们普遍认为，由于乌克兰无人机最近对莫斯科发动一波袭击，俄罗斯当局已经关闭了地理定位服务。出租车司机和我都没有向对方提及这一点：谈论战争（这里称为“svo”，一个源自俄语“特殊军事行动”单词首字母的新词）是有风险的在莫斯科，现在缺乏信任。

;

;在弗拉基米尔·普京入侵乌克兰的第一年，战争感觉很遥远，莫斯科的生活几乎一切如常。但自从五月份第一架无人机抵达俄罗斯首都以来，;这座城市已处于永久警戒状态;。夜间袭击已经增加。 7月底，无人机袭击了商业区的一座摩天大楼，接下来的一个月，他们又袭击了住宅区的建筑物。现在，无人机大约每周飞往莫斯科及周边地区一次。到目前为止，该活动尚未造成重大损害或人员伤亡，表明其主要目的是制造恐惧。

;;

;莫斯科人永远不会承认害怕，但首都有一种明显的不安感，部分原因是因为信息的碎片化。记者可以报道无人机袭击的后果，但这段视频很少出现在国家电视台的新闻简报中。八月份有;距莫斯科两小时车程的一家工厂发生爆炸。俄罗斯官员拒绝推测原因，但看起来像是乌克兰无人机袭击。

;

;莫斯科当局并没有像基辅那样用空袭警报警告无人机的接近。一旦发生袭击，莫斯科市长谢尔盖·索比亚宁通常会在他的 Telegram 频道上发布相关公告。但官员们很少透露有多少无人机参与了袭击，或者袭击了哪些地点。

;

;;一位朋友告诉我，她晚上设置了两个警报，这样她就可以跟上最新的罢工报告< /cite>;

;

;如果俄罗斯人想了解他们附近的无人机袭击，他们需要成为侦探。这意味着在互联网上搜索无人机损坏的视频，其中许多视频未经验证（商业新闻网站 ;RBK; 已开始发布经过验证的袭击报告地图，这很有帮助）。我的朋友们总是交换关于哪个 Telegram 频道信息最丰富的提示。有人告诉我，她晚上设置了两个闹钟，这样她就可以了解最新的罢工消息。

;

;;一些俄罗斯人;他们对当局对无人机袭击的严厉反应感到越来越沮丧，特别是因为这似乎并没有阻止他们。一个流传甚广的表情包显示，乌克兰总统弗拉基米尔·泽连斯基 (Volodymyr Zelensky) 驾驶着一架滑稽的低科技飞机在克里姆林宫上空愉快地飞行。

;;

;出租车服务中断主要影响中产阶级（一位担任时尚造型师的朋友担心关于开会迟到的问题，并欢迎我建议她用笑脸表情符号走向他们）。国内航班中断是一个更广泛的问题。越来越多的飞机因“运营原因”或“入境航班延误”而延误或取消，旅客现在认为这是无人机袭击的委婉说法（或旨在防止无人机袭击的信号中断）。

;

;这影响了很多人——大多数想要从俄罗斯一个地方飞往另一个地方的航空公司乘客仍然必须在莫斯科转机。首都的机场挤满了焦急的乘客，他们伸长脖子查看到达和出发的航班牌。年长的旅客或许还记得苏联时代无休无止的排队，似乎不那么焦躁。

;

;;飞机因“运营原因”或“进港航班延误”而延误或取消;

;

;如今，乘飞机出境的人少得多。自战争开始以来，西欧一直不受欢迎，俄罗斯的波罗的海和斯堪的纳维亚邻国最近对俄罗斯护照持有者关闭了边境。但伊斯坦布尔仍然是通往欧洲的门户，那里的航班也受到了影响。

;

;在国际出发休息室，穿着名牌运动装备的旅客连续等待几个小时。关于伊斯坦布尔机场购物或午睡的最佳地点的一些建议。其他人打电话回家告知航班状态的最新信息。他们在任何时候都不会提及;svo;。 ;■;

;

;Kate de Pury 是驻莫斯科的记者

; Mon, 25 Sep 2023 04:27:03 +0800 Britain’s war on drugs enters a new phase | Britainhttps://www.economist.com/britain/2023/09/21/britains-war-on-drugs-enters-a-new-phase ;
;< /div>;

;;T;;HE SHOOTING ;画廊将位于婴儿车商店的停车场后面苏格兰最大城市以东。在里面，携带海洛因或其他非法药物的吸毒者可能会在医疗监督下自杀。负责该市公共卫生决策的格拉斯哥城市一体化联合委员会将于 9 月 27 日批准其开业。值得注意的是，预计不会有反对意见。

;
;;
;

;安全吸毒室或过量预防中心（; OPCs）已在 16 个国家/地区合法化，但这将是英国的第一个。研究表明，它们不会增加吸毒量，但确实有助于让吸毒者参加其他治疗。该试点应该可以拯救许多否则会因服药过量而死亡的用户。这有可能促使该国过时的毒品政策发生急需的转变。

;
;;

;需求紧迫。 “我们正处于公共卫生紧急状态，”格拉斯哥市议员艾伦·凯西说。去年，1,051 名苏格兰人死于滥用药物。这比前一年下降了 21%，但仍是二十年前的四倍。令人担忧的是，2023年上半年毒品死亡人数再次上升。按每百万人死亡人数计算，在富裕国家中，只有美国的记录更差（见图表）。格拉斯哥和邓迪等后工业城市的死亡率最高。

;

;苏格兰的特殊问题有多种原因。最贫困地区的苏格兰人因毒品而死亡的可能性是最富裕地区的苏格兰人的 16 倍。该国吸毒问题的比例很高，这使更多的人面临风险。格拉斯哥喀里多尼亚大学的安德鲁·麦考利 (Andrew McAuley) 指出，2000 年代末，随着医生减少苯二氮卓类药物的处方，死亡人数猛增。更危险的街头品种取代了它们，它们在家庭工厂压制成药丸，然后与海洛因和其他毒品一起服用。

;

;执政 16 年的苏格兰民族党 (;SNP;) 指责威斯敏斯特实行紧缩政策，没有将毒品政策下放给荷里路德。事实上，该党也应对之前削减前线服务（包括用于康复的瘾君子的床位）负有责任。最近，苏格兰民族党投入了更多资金，并任命了一位毒品部长，但两国政府的行动都极其缓慢。

;

;对僵局感到沮丧，2020 年，活动家 Peter Krykant 在格拉斯哥的一辆小巴上发起了非法;OPC;，在九次服药过量后挽救了生命。看来他的实验集中了思想。 9 月 11 日，苏格兰首席法律官、辩护律师多萝西·贝恩 (Dorothy Bain) 表示，她的办公室不会支持起诉在试点设施中吸毒的人。苏格兰威斯敏斯特大臣阿利斯特·杰克 (Alister Jack) 证实，英国政府也不会干预（尽管内政部继续反对 ;OPC;）。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;这在全国范围内都很重要，因为更多的城市可能有勇气制定最多;OPC;。 “未来 12 至 18 个月内，我们将在威尔士和英格兰看到它们”，慈善机构转变毒品政策基金会的史蒂夫·罗尔斯 (Steve Rolles) 预测。苏格兰的毒品死亡人数约为英国其他地区的三倍，但 2021 年英格兰和威尔士有 4,859 人因吸毒过量死亡，创下历史纪录。

;

;然而，苏格兰的试点本身并没有改变法律。苏格兰政府现在希望将个人持有毒品合法化。它希望效仿葡萄牙和瑞士等国家取得的进展，这些国家的毒品死亡率要低得多。然而，苏格兰仍然受到英国 1971 年通过的惩罚性《药物滥用法》的约束。全球药物政策委员会主席海伦·克拉克 (Helen Clark) 表示，英国在减少危害方面“落后于”许多富裕国家。该委员会是一个由前世界领导人组成的游说团体。

;

;政治家不愿意走在公众舆论的前面；十分之七的英国人认为持有少量海洛因或可卡因应构成刑事犯罪。 9 月 12 日，<小>;议员;以 368 票的多数投票通过了《滥用药物法》修正案。不幸的是，他们这样做是为了加强管制——禁止销售或拥有笑气。因此，立法者们看起来越来越与他们自己的反对禁令的专家不一致。

;

;尽管如此，格拉斯哥的试点项目仍被视为非刑事化的各个小步骤之一，通过针头交换、海洛因处方和药物来勉强维持。节日期间药品安全检查。罗尔斯先生表示：“每一次，禁毒战争的言辞都会变得不太有效。”;■;

;

; Sun, 24 Sep 2023 08:27:03 +0800 A web of security guarantees could give Ukraine all the help it needs, says Fabrice Pothier | By Invitationhttps://www.economist.com/by-invitation/2023/09/22/a-web-of-security-guarantees-could-give-ukraine-all-the-help-it-needs-says-fabrice-pothier ;
;< /div>;

;;W;;身为前演员的总统;，很容易看到乌克兰的最近对俄罗斯的防御作为续集。称为第一年生存率；第二，长期战争。

;

;在我访问乌克兰时，没有人明确这样称呼它。但这场史诗般斗争的所有主角都在为这场长期战争做准备。基辅领导人面临的问题是如何坚持对抗无法取胜却拒绝放弃的敌人。

;

;乌克兰面临着国内的重大挑战和不断变化的国外政治风向。在国内，必须赢得一场反腐败的内部战争，以维持民众和国际捐助者的支持。人口统计正在成为一个重大的长期问题。俄罗斯的人口是乌克兰的三倍半，因此可以调用的人力要多得多。即使有数百万乌克兰人回国，仍有约 15% 的乌克兰人留在国外中欧和西欧。在国外生活、工作和抚养孩子的时间越多，回国就越困难。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;一代留在家里的年轻人正在战斗。墓地里挂满了 2000 年代出生的男性的旗帜和照片；非官方估计表明，在这场通常被比作第一次世界大战凡尔登战壕的冲突中，已有五十万人丧生或受伤。整整一代的“gueules cassées”将影响战后社会和政治，带来社会紧张、犯罪和更激进观点的风险。长期战争可能会给乌克兰的社会结构带来压力。

;

;在经济上，该国正处于生命维持状态。大约 30% 的 GDP 用于战争，而国际捐助者只是让乌克兰免于财政崩溃。中小型企业正在努力维持生计。弗拉基米尔·普京从粮食出口开始扼杀乌克兰经济的企图将会成功，除非基辅能够重新获得对其黑海航线的更大控制。

;

;再加上战场上进展缓慢。领土是一步一步地、一米一米地夺回的，任何进展都依赖于长期的系统性支持，无论是在武器供应方面还是在建设乌克兰国防工业基地方面。

;

;这就是为什么七月份签署了一份联合声明的原因弗拉基米尔·泽连斯基总统和七国集团领导人在立陶宛维尔纽斯举行的北约峰会期间发表的讲话意义重大。去年的大部分时间里，我与<小>;北约;前负责人安德斯·福格·拉斯穆森(Anders Fogh Rasmussen)以及泽连斯基先生的幕僚长安德烈·叶尔马克(Andriy Yermak)一起致力于安全保障工作，该声明是这项工作的重要成果。这不仅仅是一线希望：在精心谈判的措辞背后是主要盟友的一系列承诺，只要乌克兰需要，就向其提供所需的一切。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;自维尔纽斯峰会以来，已有 25 个其他国家政府和;欧盟;加入了该宣言，使32 的潜在担保人。未来几个月预计还会有更多担保人。

;

;与 1994 年签署的布达佩斯备忘录进行比较是有启发性的。该文件是一项与乌克兰加入《核不扩散条约》相关的安全保证协议，提出了崇高的承诺，但在 2014 年俄罗斯袭击乌克兰时没有做出任何回应。<小>;G7 ;协议旨在就像美国对以色列的双边承诺一样：通过长期提供关键资源来增强乌克兰的自卫能力。

;

;然而，这并不是像《北约》宪章第五条那样的共同防御协议。签署国没有承诺向乌克兰派遣自己的士兵，以防未来发生侵略。它的目的是作为乌克兰加入;北约;的桥梁，而不是替代品。

;

;先是签约，然后是谈判，目前尚未开始。达成 32 项不同的双边协议将是一项艰巨的任务，而三项测试将表明所有这些交易是否能够真正帮助乌克兰应对长期战争。

;

;首先，时间范围是多少？为了有意义，承诺必须超越短期决策周期。这里有积极的迹象。 ;欧盟;提出了 200 亿欧元（210 亿美元）的四年国防资金承诺。美国正在幕后制定一揽子计划，远远超出本周在国会陷入困境的 240 亿美元提案。德国承诺在未来七年内提供武器和联合生产。

;

;第二个考验是确保签署方信守诺言。这是谈判最困难的地方，特别是考虑到美国过去不愿签署具有约束力的国际协议。维持两党对在美国国会编纂该协议至关重要，因为这是抵御可能对乌克兰持怀疑态度的未来总统的堡垒。与此同时，基辅必须在推动达成实质性和有约束力的协议与承认担保国的政治现实之间取得平衡。一种解决方案可能是现在专注于制定实际协议（所谓的谅解备忘录），将所有这些承诺置于通用的国际法律框架下，最终得到所有签署方的批准。

;

;最后，这些协议必须通过商定协商机制来区别于《布达佩斯备忘录》。这可能与;北约;宪章第4条相呼应：一个盟友可以呼吁所有其他国家分担安全担忧并评估威胁。 ;G7;可以与乌克兰协调这一努力，揭示与临时双边支持截然不同的承诺，并在必要时迅速调整。

;

;任何一场长期的消耗战都没有单一、简单的胜利之路，而只是一场艰苦的意志较量。在此背景下，谈判并商定长期安全保障发出了一个强烈信号，表明莫斯科拖延时间的策略不会成功。这种保证不仅仅意味着更多的武器。对泽连斯基来说，这是一种旨在说服数百万勤劳的乌克兰人返回家园并重建国家的政策。如果他成功了，那么 2024 年有望推出三部曲的最后一部续集——描绘持久的和平。 ;■;

;

;;Fabrice Pothier 是政治咨询公司 Rasmussen Global 的首席执行官，也是前;北约;成员政策规划总监。;

; Sun, 24 Sep 2023 08:27:03 +0800 America’s states are trying to set rules for the internet | United Stateshttps://www.economist.com/united-states/2023/09/21/americas-states-are-trying-to-set-rules-for-the-internet ;
;< /div>;

;;自从美国在线的不和谐音调标志着进展缓慢以来，互联网已经发生了一些变化在线连接速度甚至更慢。但联邦和州立法者一直在努力跟上监管政策。加利福尼亚州州长加文·纽瑟姆 (Gavin Newsom) 于 2022 年 9 月签署了新的儿童在线安全法，本应纠正这一问题。儿童安全倡导者希望这将成为监管互联网的重要一步。然而，一名联邦法官介入，在儿童安全和言论自由之间引发了价值观冲突。

;
;;
;

;包括 Google 和 Meta 在内的贸易组织 NetChoice 起诉加利福尼亚州以第一修正案为由。 9 月 18 日，地区法院法官贝丝·拉布森·弗里曼 (Beth Labson Freeman) 暂时阻止了该法律。加利福尼亚州本应走在前面；相反，它看起来像是对其他想要这样做的州的警告。

;

;这项法律被称为《加州适龄设计规范法案》，原定于 2024 年 7 月生效，并且需要在线平台以更加敏感的方式对待儿童。加州立法者、该法律的合著者巴菲·威克斯 (Buffy Wicks) 表示，汽车座椅、婴儿床和睡衣对儿童有特殊规定。 “孩子们在线访问的产品应该有类似的消费者保护法规。”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;加利福尼亚州的法律以英国《适龄设计规范》为蓝本，该法规于 2020 年生效。如果加利福尼亚州的法律经受住了法律挑战，公司将需要谨慎对待如何收集个人信息，例如儿童所在的位置。一些公司可能会选择禁用不在其网络中的儿童和成人之间的直接消息。其他人可能会选择关闭自动播放功能或打开儿童就寝时间提醒。

;

;加州的法案签署后，其他州也纷纷效仿。佛罗里达州和康涅狄格州也制定了类似的法案。其他州则较少关注设计，而更多地关注让父母对孩子可以在网上做什么有发言权。犹他州州长三月份签署了两项法律，要求儿童必须征得父母同意才能使用社交媒体。该州还禁止未成年人在晚上 10:30 至早上 6:30 之间使用这些网站，并要求公司对伤害儿童的行为承担责任。犹他州的法律将于 2024 年 3 月生效。路易斯安那州也将于明年夏天开始实施类似的法律。阿肯色州的另一项法律原定于今年 9 月生效，但也被联邦法官暂时阻止。

;

;大部分法律阻力都是基于言论自由。 “任何限制年轻人获取某些材料的能力的法律……都会敲响警钟，”卡温顿与华盛顿大学的梅根·克劳利 (Megan Crowley) 说道。柏林，一家律师事务所。她曾代表科技公司处理第一修正案案件。 “最高法院已经明确表示儿童享有第一修正案的权利，”她说。威克斯女士希望该法律能够经受住法律挑战，但圣克拉拉大学法学教授埃里克·戈德曼对此表示怀疑。他说，第一修正案“对我们来说是非常基础的东西”。 “我们愿意为此与英国开战。”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;其他试图监管科技的州也引发了争议。今年 7 月，色情中心 Pornhub 在弗吉尼亚州通过一项法律，要求用户验证年龄才能访问色情网站后，封锁了其在弗吉尼亚州的网站。八月，一位联邦法官阻止了德克萨斯州的一项类似法律。 NetChoice 正在起诉德克萨斯州和佛罗里达州的法律，这些法律阻止社交媒体公司监管内容，例如消除极端主义政治观点。该案可能会在下个任期内提交最高法院。加州的挫折可能会让州立法者犹豫不决，但关于谁统治网络的法律斗争才刚刚开始。;■;

;;S;;从远处看;，内湖应该看起来像一片闪闪发光的内海。不列颠群岛最大的淡水湖为约 750,000 人（占北爱尔兰人口的 40%）提供饮用水，也是深受人们喜爱的钓鱼、游泳和其他休闲场所。或者至少以前是这样。如今，它的大部分水体都被污泥堵塞，表面呈发光绿色。

;
;;
;

;站在克兰菲尔德角，湖的北岸，散发着恶臭凝结的粘液可能会让人难以承受。丢弃的垃圾无法沉入胶水中。标志警告想要游泳的人留在岸上并让宠物靠近。危险来自一种蓝绿藻——蓝细菌，它产生的毒素足以杀死奶牛。天鹅、狗和狐狸都死了。据说在海湾停留的候鸟数量大大减少。

;多种因素可以解释细菌的大量生长。几十年来，由于农场肥料流失和废水（包括污水）倾倒，养分不断积累。过去十年，随着附近养殖的猪和家禽数量猛增，陆地上和水中的淤泥排放量也激增。更猛烈的降雨可能会从田地里冲走更多的养分。自 1995 年以来，海水温度也升高了 1°C。斑马贝等入侵物种的到来是另一个问题。作为滤食性动物，它首先使水变得更清澈，让阳光穿透得更深，从而促进藻类生长。

;
;
;

;
;
;
;
;
;

;
;
;
;
;
;

;< /div>;

;;W;;hen rabea;，来自黎巴嫩北部的黎波里的一名小毒贩， 2017 年，他因携带两公斤哈希被抓，他知道会发生什么。他将在当地的库巴监狱度过接下来的五年，那里已经关满了来自附近的人。他知道要见法官要等待多年。他还听说过拥挤的牢房，里面有 60 名被拘留者轮流睡在地板上，还听说过帮派和斗殴事件。

;
;;
;

;但拉贝亚并不知道事情会变得更糟。 2019年，他刑期过半，黎巴嫩经济陷入崩溃。该国的经济危机（其<小>;国内生产总值;收缩了近 40%）给监狱造成了严重破坏。 Food and medical supplies became ever scarcer and violence surged in jails that are now at 323% of capacity.

;

;Amid a multitude of crises, the welfare of Lebanon's prisoners is not a priority. The budget for the interior ministry, which runs the prisons, has officially increased in recent years. But a collapsing currency—the lira has lost 98% of its value since 2019—and soaring annual inflation (official figures put it at over 250% in July) mean that its purchasing power has been steadily eroded.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Inflation also means that families struggle to afford to buy food to supplement prisoners' increasingly meagre rations. By the end of his sentence, Rabea says he was expected to survive on as little as a spoonful of bulgar wheat a day. Amid budget cuts, prisoners are being denied crucial medical treatment. More than 800 were taken to hospital in 2018; only 107 were taken in 2022, even as the total prison population has remained stable, according to Amnesty International, a human-rights charity. Deaths in prisons almost doubled between 2018 and 2022.

;

;Meanwhile, the vast majority of Lebanese detainees are technically not guilty—not yet at least. Some 82% of prisoners have yet to see a judge, compared with 54% in 2017. When Rabea at last had his day in court, he had already been in jail for almost three years. Budget cuts within the justice ministry are slowing the government's ability to clear the backlog, so the proportion of detainees in pre-trial detention is expected to grow. In 2022 just 2,672 criminals were convicted compared with 4,772 in 2020. Strikes by judicial officials and shrinking resources are making the problem worse. At least one recent trial was suspended when prison wardens had insufficient petrol to transport the accused to court.

;

;Time keeps draggin' on

;

;When Rabea was released in 2022 almost everyone in his cell was awaiting trial. Some had been incarcerated for ten years, he says, only to be handed a one-year sentence. He watched with envy as a lucky few took advantage of the country's chaos to secure a quicker release. “If you've got money, you can pay a good lawyer and he can get your case torn up,” Rabea says. “But if you haven't, you're not going anywhere.”;■;

;;J;;ingu Baseball Stadium ;in Tokyo has seen many iconic moments in its century-old history. Babe Ruth played there in 1934, on a tour of Japan that confirmed baseball's popularity in the country and led to its first professional team. Over half a million Tokyoites lined the streets to welcome the Bambino and his teammates.

;
;;
;

;A plan to demolish the stadium, as part of a broader redevelopment of the central Jingu Gaien area, is therefore proving controversial. Over 220,000 people have signed an online petition against the redevelopment; thousands have showed up to protest against it.

;

;It is the next phase of a project launched before the Olympic Games that Tokyo hosted in 2020, which included construction of a new national stadium next to the baseball one. In the process the city eased regulations against high-rise buildings in the area. By levelling and replacing the baseball stadium and a nearby rugby one, it aims to turn Jingu Gaien into a “world-class sports cluster”, which would also include two soaring towers, a shopping area and hotels.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;To erect skyscrapers at the site, first developed as a recreational area in 1926 to honour the Meiji emperor, would be “sacrilegious”, says Ishikawa Mikiko of ;ICOMOS,; a ;UNESCO ;advisory body. Ohashi Satoko, an architect, says the existing baseball stadium, which was renovated in 2014 to be made earthquake-proof, should be maintained. She accuses the city's officials of being trapped in the “scrap and build” mentality that defined Tokyo's urban planning in the 1960s, a time of rapid economic growth and change in the metropolis.

;

;Some baseball fans raise practical concerns, suggesting the planned skyscrapers could cause disruptive winds at the new stadium. Rampant redevelopment of baseball stadiums in America suggests such worries can be exaggerated. Of the dozens that hosted Babe Ruth, two remain, Fenway Park in Boston and Wrigley Field in Chicago. After Jingu Stadium goes, Koshien Stadium in Kobe will be the only other survivor.;■;

; Sat, 23 Sep 2023 19:27:02 +0800 Brazil’s hinterland now resembles Texas | The Americashttps://www.economist.com/the-americas/2023/09/21/brazils-hinterland-now-resembles-texas ;
;
;

;;T;;HINK OF BRAZIL; and, if you're like most people, you'll think of palm-lined beaches, samba and caipirinhas. The cliché needs updating. In the past two decades the centre of political and economic gravity has started shifting from the humid coasts, to which Brazilians were said to cling “like crabs”, to the vast, arid plains of the interior. Its soundtrack is ;sertanejo; (country music). The preferred beverage is cold beer.

;
;;
;
;;

;Brazil's census, its first in 12 years, showed a notable trend when it was published in June. Seven of the ten municipalities that have grown most are in the farmbelt in the southern half of the country and the centre-west. The population of the centre-west, which includes the states of Goiás, Mato Grosso and Mato Grosso do Sul plus the capital, Brasília (see map), grew by 1.2% a year, more than double the national rate. The south-east still has the most people and money—São Paulo state alone produces a third of Brazil's ;GDP; and is home to a fifth of its population. But even within that state, it is in the farmbelt where the population and economy are growing most.

;

;Migrations within Brazil are nothing new. A movement from the poor north-east to the industrial hub around the city of São Paulo did much to shape the country's economy and culture in the second half of the 20th century. Brazil's current president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, is the most famous of the millions who made that journey. After a famine struck his birthplace in Pernambuco, his mother packed her eight children onto a ;pau de arara; (macaw's perch), a flatbed truck, and headed south. Lula rose to prominence as a trade-union leader in the car industry near São Paulo. Now when people leave the poor north-east they tend to head to the interior. What has changed is the perception of which activity can offer better lives, says Carlos Vian of the University of São Paulo. “Before, it was industry; not any more.”

;

;The magnet that drew Lula to São Paulo has lost strength. In the mid-1980s manufacturing accounted for a third of Brazil's ;GDP;; now it represents just 10%. The country's surplus in manufacturing trade, $6bn in 2005, became a deficit of $108bn by 2019. Productivity in manufacturing and services has stagnated or shrunk.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;

;Cultivation, the basis of Brazil's economy in the 19th century, has made a comeback. The country still exports coffee and sugar, which were once grown on plantations worked by slaves. Since the early 2000s voracious demand from China has encouraged a rise in production of soyabeans, grains and meat (see chart). Agricultural exports as a share of the total have more than quadrupled since 2000, to 40%. Today the sector accounts for a quarter of ;GDP; and employs a similar share of workers. From 2002 to 2020 the economy of Mato Grosso, the soyabean heartland, grew by 4.7% a year in real terms, more than that of any other state and more than double the national rate.

;

;The agri-business boom is slowly changing demography and culture. In the 1970s, more than four-fifths of population growth occurred in the biggest cities. In the past 12 years, during which the population grew more slowly, two-thirds of the growth has taken place in mid-size towns.

;

;Sinop, a soyabean centre in Mato Grosso, typifies the trend. The state, whose name means “dense forest”, had few inhabitants until the middle of the 20th century. A succession of Brazilian governments set out to populate the country's hinterland. Agencies were established to offer land and cheap credit to people who moved west. They flourished during a military dictatorship, which ruled from 1964 to 1985. Sinop, founded in 1974, is named after one such company.

;

;Life at first was hard for the settlers (though harder for the indigenous people they pushed out). The rust-coloured earth yielded little and disease was rampant. Technology came to the rescue. In the 1980s Embrapa, the national agricultural-research agency, developed a variety of soyabean that thrived in the region's acidic soils. Among the beneficiaries was the father of Juliano Antoniolli, who arrived in Sinop in 1981, before farms had access to electricity. Back then, downtown was “just a big mud bath”, says Mr Antoniolli, a 38-year-old farmer.

;
;

;Now 4,000 head of cattle roam alongside the soyabean fields and rows of maize on his 2,400 hectares near Sinop. Drones spray fertiliser and John Deere tractors pull ploughs. Three base stations from Starlink, owned by Elon Musk, connect the farm to the internet. Mr Antoniolli employs 12 people full-time, plus temporary workers during the harvest. He pays an average wage of 8,000 reais ($1,600) a month, three times Brazil's median salary. He sells most of his produce to ;cofco;, a Chinese food giant.

;

;Sertanejo's soft power

;

;Thanks to the money and jobs brought by the farming boom, not just for farmhands but for construction workers and others, Sinop's population has swelled by 73% in the past 12 years, to 200,000. Now a city of roundabouts and car dealerships, it resembles a settlement in the United States' deep South more than Brazil's coastal metropolises. A petrol station calls itself Texas; a butcher, Super Beef.

;

;With economic clout comes other sorts of influence. ;Sertanejo; is Brazil's most popular music. In 2003 16% of the top songs on Brazilian radio were of that genre. By 2022 three-quarters were. A sub-genre, ;agronejo;, praises big agriculture. Luan Pereira, a lanky singer, wrote a hit song about fooling around in a Dodge Ram, a muscular American pickup truck favoured by soya barons. The video has been viewed almost 100m times in the past six months on YouTube. Some country singers style themselves “roughs”, as opposed to “playboys” from the city. “Five playboys can't do what one rough can,” boasts a cowboy-hatted DJ Kévin, joined by Mr Pereira.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;;Sertanejo; self-confidence poses a challenge for Lula and his government. On the one hand, they welcome the economic growth that comes with agricultural expansion. On the other, they worry about its environmental cost and its political implications. Farmland is growing partly at the expense of the ;cerrado; (tropical savannah), Brazil's second-largest biome after the Amazon. Its owners tend to be fans of Jair Bolsonaro, the right-wing president whom Lula defeated in the election last year. (Indeed, according to a news website, Mr Antoniolli was present in January this year when supporters of the former president attacked federal buildings in Brasília to protest against Lula's inauguration. He told the website that he left as soon as the vandalism began.) In response to the census, Brazil's Supreme Court in August ordered the first reapportionment of seats in the lower house of Congress since 1993. The Lula-friendly north-east will lose; the farmbelt will gain.

;

;Lula began his third term in January (he had been president from 2003 to 2010) as a foe of farming and ranching. During the election campaign he proposed limiting beef exports to hold down domestic prices. Yet he has since tried to get along with agri-business, offering more support while cajoling it to be greener. On June 27th he announced 364bn reais of subsidised loans to farmers, Brazil's biggest-ever agricultural-credit plan. Farmers who use renewable energy and non-chemical pesticides will qualify for the cheapest loans. The national development bank, set up in the 1950s to promote industry, is shifting towards financing agriculture. In 2009 agri-business received just 5% of the bank's loans. Last year nearly a quarter of its financing went to agriculture, and less than a fifth to industry. The balance is unlikely to shift back under Lula's government.

;

;Many farmers profess to support the government's push to make farming greener. Daniel Freire, the head of a chain of slaughterhouses in Pará, an Amazonian state, says that his company needs environmental permits to export to Europe and the United States. “To ship to the best markets in the world, it's important to improve our sanitary and environmental standards,” he says. In April the European Parliament passed a law that from the end of next year will oblige producers of commodities to verify that their goods have not contributed to deforestation since 2020.

;

;But privately many farmers grumble about environmental rules. They oppose, and sometimes flout, the national forest code, which obliges farmers in the ;cerrado; to maintain native vegetation on 20-35% of their land. Some growers and ranchers move into the rainforest in states such as Pará, where the requirement is stricter (80% of their forest has to be preserved) but enforcement is even weaker.

;

;Brazil is one of the few countries where farmland is still expanding. The ;us; Department of Agriculture estimates that by 2031 another 20m hectares, close to a quarter of the area now planted with crops, will be brought into production. Growth need not mean destroying trees. Some 170m hectares of pasture are thought to be under-used. If farmers grew soyabeans on just 10m of those hectares, they could raise output by 40m tonnes a year over the next decade, roughly a tenth of today's global output, says Daniel Amaral of the Association of Brazilian Vegetable Oil Industries. The productivity of each hectare could also increase. Brazilian maize farmers grow an average of six metric tonnes per hectare, half the yields American farmers achieve. Better infrastructure could boost profits and investment. The lorries that carry Mato Grosso's grains to port must travel along a single 1,000km pothole-filled road. Brazil's logistics costs are the equivalent of 12.1% of gross national product, compared with 7.6% in the United States. Farmers have much to gain from a government that would invest in reducing them.

;

;In places like Sinop the future looks bright. But fears are growing that the success of Brazil's farmers could contain the seeds of its undoing. Deforestation of the ;cerrado; could eventually reduce rainfall. Already signs of stress from global climate change are beginning to appear. ;Sertanejo; could some day lose its swagger. ;■;

;
;;
;

;The most eye-catching was a lawsuit filed on September 15th by the Democrat-led state government accusing five big oil companies—;BP;, Chevron, ConocoPhillips, ExxonMobil and Shell—of lying about the dangers of climate change.州立法机构几天前通过的两项法案可能会产生更大的影响。他们可以在美国首次迫使大企业披露与气候相关的信息。 Governor Gavin Newsom vowed to sign both, after a few tweaks.

;

;The two approaches—legal and legislative—were hailed by climate campaigners as tipping points in American law.针对“石油巨头”的诉讼旨在让被告为加州因使用其产品而遭受的环境损害付出代价。这些公司重申了对脱碳的承诺，并表示法院不是解决如此重大问题的合适场所。这是近年来各州和城市针对化石燃料生产商提起的数十起法庭案件中最新且最重要的一起。这些诉讼进展缓慢，到目前为止，还没有公司败诉。 But in April the Supreme Court dealt a blow to oil producers by rejecting their efforts to move such cases from state to federal courts.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The two laws are likely to have bigger, and more immediate, consequences.他们要求在加州开展业务的大公司披露其温室气体排放和与气候相关的脆弱性。它们是美国首个此类标准，并且像该州的车辆排放标准一样，其影响可能远远超出加州的范围。

;

;One applies to more than 5,000 companies with global annual revenues of over $1bn, and obliges them to disclose direct and indirect emissions, known as scope 1 and scope 2, beginning in 2026. A year later, they must also reveal their scope 3 emissions, which include those generated by their suppliers and end users.例如，汽车制造商必须考虑向其提供零部件的人和驾驶汽车的人的排放量。范围 3 排放量很难计算，而且可能是直接排放量的很多倍，这使得一些公司不愿意计算它们。

;

;The second measure applies to 10,000 or so companies with revenues above $500m.从 2026 年开始，他们必须每隔一年提交一份报告，了解气候变化对其业务的财务影响。科技巨头微软和服装品牌巴塔哥尼亚等一些公司对这些措施表示支持。游说团体加州商会反对他们，认为他们会在不限制排放的情况下推高企业的合规成本。即便如此，企业仍会发现难以抗拒加州巨大市场的诱惑。

;

;The climate-disclosure requirements come shortly before America's Securities and Exchange Commission (;SEC;), a regulator, is expected to launch something similar at a federal level. Michael Gerrard of the Sabin Centre for Climate Change Law at Columbia University points out that the ;SEC;'s rule is narrower in scope than California's, only affects publicly traded companies above a certain size, and may be more legally vulnerable.

;

;Internationally, California is not alone.许多美国跨国公司很快将不得不遵守欧盟更严格的气候信息披露要求。美国的共和党州可能会抱怨治外法权。 But when it comes to standard-setting, businesses know they must take California and the ;EU; seriously. ;■;
